definition: to rise to the sky/to lift off/to levitate/liftoff
to ascend/to rise to the rank of/to promote/to hoist/liter/measure for dry grain equal to one-tenth dou 斗[dou3]
variant of 升[sheng1]/to ascend/to rise in rank

sentences.english: It will not mean things like levitating objects and reading others minds.
sentences.chinese: 它不会是把物体升空和看穿别人的心思之类的事。

sentences.english: It's the next best thing to witnessing an actual blastoff.
sentences.chinese: 这是仅次于目睹火箭真实升空的最佳选择。

sentences.english: The aircraft's undercarriage retracted as it climbed into the air.
sentences.chinese: 飞机的起落架在升空时即可缩回。

sentences.english: The spaceship named pluto no. 4 will be launched by the united states .
sentences.chinese: 太空船布鲁特四号将由美国发射升空。

sentences.english: Above, an artist's conception of the Space Launch System blasting off.
sentences.chinese: 图中，艺术家设想的太空发射系统点火升空了。

sentences.english: As the roaring rocket rose, the restless roosters rollicked.
sentences.chinese: 呼啸的火箭升空，不安分的公鸡喧闹。

sentences.english: Aerostat is one of lifted-up platforms of radar.
sentences.chinese: 浮空器是雷达的升空平台之一。

sentences.english: Careers, like rockets, don't always take lff on schedule.
sentences.chinese: 事业就像火箭并非总是依时升空。

sentences.english: The launch was six days after her 40th birthday.
sentences.chinese: 她升空那天是她40岁生日零6天。

sentences.english: The spaceship will lift off from the launching pad at 7 a. m.
sentences.chinese: 宇宙飞船将于上午七时由发射台发射升空。

sentences.english: The rocket blasted off successfully from the Japanese space center on Tanegashima Island in the Pacific Ocean.
sentences.chinese: 火箭从太平洋上的种子岛太空中心成功发射升空。

sentences.english: The space shuttle had been scheduled to blast off at 04:38.
sentences.chinese: 航天飞机已经预定于凌晨4点38分发射升空。

sentences.english: A prototype spaceplane developed for the US military has been launched into orbit from Florida.
sentences.chinese: 一架美国军用航天飞机在佛罗里达州发射升空。

sentences.english: But in terms of5 when we were launching, I was probably the calmest all day.
sentences.chinese: 真到了发射升空时，却可能是我全天最平静的时候。

definition: to shoot (a projectile)/to fire (a rocket)/to launch/to emit (a particle)/to discharge/emanation/emission
to form into columns/to organize into teams/formation (of ships or aircraft)
to return to the point of departure
